definition: The act or process of separating into parts; in maths, the operation of finding how many times one number is contained in another; a disagreement that separates people.
examples: We practised long division in maths today.
There was a division of labour among the groups.
The issue caused a deep division in opinion.

definition: Relating to the mind or thinking; done in the head without writing.
examples: We did mental maths before the quiz.
Creating a mental picture can help you remember.

definition: The result or effect of an action or event.
examples: The outcome of the experiment matched our hypothesis.
The match outcome was a draw.

extra.memory_tip: Outcome = what comes out at the end.

definition: An activity that you enjoy doing in your free time; a hobby.
examples: Reading is her favourite pastime.
Gardening is a relaxing pastime.

definition: To help something grow, happen, or become well known; to raise someone to a higher position.
examples: Our posters promote the school play.
The club promotes healthy habits.
She was promoted to team leader.

extra.memory_tip: Promote = move it ‘up’ or make it more known.

definition: A measure of how often or how much something happens; a price; to judge or value something.
examples: Her heart rate increased during exercise. (noun)
The hotel’s room rate was affordable. (noun)
How would you rate the book? (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Rate = the pace, the price, or the score.

definition: A feeling of sadness about something that has happened; to feel sorry about something.
examples: He felt regret after speaking unkindly. (noun)
I regret missing your call. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Regret = wish you could ‘re-get’ the moment.

definition: A natural ability to do something well.
examples: She has a talent for drawing animals.
The show looks for new musical talent.

extra.memory_tip: Talent = a gift you can train into skill.

definition: A well-supported explanation of how or why something happens; an idea used to explain facts.
examples: Evolution is a scientific theory supported by evidence.
Her theory about the puzzle was correct.

extra.memory_tip: Theory = a thoughtful ‘story’ that explains facts.

definition: A series of contests between many players or teams, with one overall winner.
examples: Our school entered a football tournament.
She won the chess tournament last spring.

extra.memory_tip: Tournament = turn by turn until a champion remains.
